bestBHT.bht: The marketplace idle, where men and masters gather for bargaining, is set in contrast to the vineyard of the Kingdom of God. It is in this place that the workers stand idle, waiting to be hired. This depiction symbolizes the spiritual state of God's elect before their calling, where they belong to the marketplace, exhibiting sluggishness and a reluctance to work, fearing even a little trouble. However, God seeks them out and calls them from this posture, bringing them into His Kingdom through His grace and the preaching of His Gospel.

Henry Alford: The market-place of the world is contrasted with the vineyard of the Kingdom of God.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: After a fourth of the working day had expired: the day of twelve hours was reckoned from six to six.
Albert Barnes: About the third hour - The Jews divided their days into twelve equal parts, or hours, beginning at sunrise and ending at sunset. This was, therefore about nine o’clock in the morning.
Standing idle in the market-place - A place where provisions are sold in towns. Of course, many resort to such places, and it would be the readiest place to meet persons and find employers.
They were not, therefore, disposed to be idle, but were waiting in the proper place to find employers.
Philip Schaff: The greatest man of business on the market-place of the world is a mere idle gazer."
About nine o’clock in the morning, when the market-place would be full.
Archibald T. Robertson: The market place was the place where men and masters met for bargaining.
We observed every morning, before the sun rose, that a numerous band of peasants were collected, with spades in their hands, waiting to be hired for the day to work in the surrounding fields.
John Gill: Now God's elect before calling, are in this place: they are natives of it, have their conversation according to it.
Here Christ came in person, and here he sends his ministers, his Gospel, to find them out, and by his Spirit and grace he calls them from hence.
But before conversion they belong to it, and their posture then is standing idle; being sluggish, and slothful in business, unwilling to work, and afraid of a little danger and trouble.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Matthew 20:3, the marketplace of the world is contrasted with the vineyard of the Kingdom of God. The market place was where men and masters met for bargaining, and the workers stood idle, waiting to be hired. This image of the marketplace idle signifies a spiritual state in which God's elect, before their calling, belong to this place and are sluggish and slothful in business, unwilling to work and afraid of a little danger and trouble. However, God seeks them out and calls them from this state, bringing them into His Kingdom.

In the contrast between the marketplace of the world and the vineyard of the Kingdom of God, we see a depiction of idle workers waiting to be hired. These individuals are reluctant to work, exhibiting sluggishness and a fear of any potential trouble. However, it is in this place that God's elect are found before their calling, as they belong to this spiritual state. Nevertheless, God seeks them out, calls them, and brings them into His Kingdom.

The marketplace of the world, where men and masters meet for bargaining, contrasts with the vineyard of the Kingdom of God. In this depiction, the workers are observed standing idle, waiting to be hired. Before conversion, God's elect are part of this state, reluctant to work, appearing sluggish and slothful in business, and fearful of trouble. However, through His grace and the calling of His ministers, God seeks them out from the marketplace and brings them into His Kingdom.

The marketplace idle, where men and masters gather for bargaining, is set in contrast to the vineyard of the Kingdom of God. It is in this place that the workers stand idle, waiting to be hired. This depiction symbolizes the spiritual state of God's elect before their calling, where they belong to the marketplace, exhibiting sluggishness and a reluctance to work, fearing even a little trouble. However, God seeks them out and calls them from this posture, bringing them into His Kingdom through His grace and the preaching of His Gospel.

In the contrasting imagery of the marketplace idle and the vineyard of the Kingdom of God, the spiritual state of God's elect before their calling is revealed. The workers, standing idle in the marketplace, are hesitant to work and afraid of trouble. This reluctance and slothfulness depict their sluggishness in business and their belonging to this place. However, through His grace, God seeks them out, calls them, and brings them into His Kingdom, transforming their posture and purpose.
